questions.question: Per OSHA 1926.501, fall protection is required when working at heights above:
questions.explanation: OSHA 1926.501(b)(1) requires fall protection for construction workers at 6 feet or more above a lower level. This applies to most residential and commercial PV roof installations. Fall protection includes guardrails, safety nets, or personal fall arrest systems.

questions.question: A personal fall arrest system (PFAS) consists of:

options.text: Full body harness, lanyard/SRL, and anchor point

questions.explanation: A complete PFAS includes a full-body harness worn by the worker, a connecting device (lanyard or self-retracting lifeline), and an anchor point rated for 5,000 lbs or designed by a qualified person for the intended load.

questions.question: Per OSHA, anchor points for personal fall arrest systems must be capable of supporting:
questions.explanation: OSHA 1926.502(d)(15) requires anchorages for personal fall arrest to support 5,000 lbs per employee attached, or be designed by a qualified person with a safety factor of 2. Roof anchors must be properly installed to structural members.

questions.question: When using an extension ladder to access a roof, the ladder should extend above the landing surface by at least:
questions.explanation: OSHA 1926.1053(b)(1) requires ladders to extend at least 3 feet above the upper landing surface when used for roof access. This provides a handhold for safe transition on and off the ladder.

questions.question: The proper angle for setting up an extension ladder is approximately:
questions.explanation: The 4-to-1 rule: for every 4 feet of height, the base should be 1 foot from the wall (approximately 75° angle). This provides optimal stability. Too steep risks tipping backward; too shallow risks sliding out.

questions.question: What PPE is required when working with PV systems?

options.text: Safety glasses, gloves, hard hat, and appropriate footwear at minimum

questions.explanation: Basic PPE for PV installation includes safety glasses (debris/UV protection), work gloves (cuts, module edges), hard hat (overhead hazards), and sturdy footwear with good traction. Additional PPE depends on specific hazards present.

questions.question: Before working on DC PV circuits, what should be done first?

options.text: Open disconnects, verify zero energy, and cover modules if possible

questions.explanation: PV arrays produce power whenever exposed to light. Open all accessible disconnects, use a meter to verify zero voltage, and cover modules with opaque material if working on energized circuits is unavoidable. Use insulated tools and PPE.

questions.question: Covering PV modules with opaque material reduces voltage to approximately:
questions.explanation: Even covered modules produce some voltage from ambient light. Complete darkness reduces Voc to near zero, but opaque covers typically reduce to 10-20% of full sun voltage. Verify with meter before assuming de-energized.

questions.question: Which residential roof type is most common for PV installations in the US?
questions.explanation: Asphalt shingle (composition) roofing is the most common residential roof type in the US. Standard roof attachments with flashing work well with this material. Other roof types require specialized mounting hardware.

questions.question: When installing on a standing seam metal roof, the preferred attachment method is:

options.text: Non-penetrating clamps that grip the seam

questions.explanation: Standing seam clamps grip the raised seams without penetrating the roof membrane, preserving waterproofing. Various clamp styles fit different seam profiles. This attachment method is faster and eliminates potential leak points.

questions.question: Tile roofs require special care during PV installation because:

options.text: Tiles are fragile and break easily under foot traffic

questions.explanation: Clay and concrete tiles break easily when walked on. Use foam pads, walk on the lower third of tiles, and use tile hooks that replace or work with existing tiles. Broken tiles must be replaced to maintain waterproofing.

questions.question: The primary purpose of roof flashing at PV attachment points is to:
questions.explanation: Flashings are metal or composite plates installed under roofing material around lag bolt penetrations. They channel water away from the penetration, preventing leaks. Proper flashing installation is critical for long-term roof integrity.

questions.question: When installing flashings on an asphalt shingle roof, the flashing should be placed:

options.text: Under upper shingles and over lower shingles

questions.explanation: Flashings are woven into the shingle pattern: the upper portion slides under the shingles above, while the lower portion overlaps the shingles below. This sheds water like fish scales and prevents water from reaching the penetration.

questions.question: Lag bolts for PV roof attachments should penetrate into the rafter by at least:
questions.explanation: Most manufacturer specifications require 1.5-2 inches of thread engagement in solid wood. The total lag length must account for roofing material, sheathing, and required penetration. Longer lags may be needed for thick roofing assemblies.

questions.question: Before installing a lag bolt, a pilot hole should be drilled that is:

options.text: The same diameter as the lag
Approximately 70% of the lag shank diameter

questions.explanation: Pilot holes prevent wood splitting and ensure proper thread engagement. The hole diameter should be about 70% of the lag shank (for the unthreaded portion) and 60-70% of root diameter for the threaded portion in dense wood.

questions.question: What is the most reliable method to locate roof rafters for PV attachment?

options.text: Attic inspection and measurement from reference points
Use a magnet on the roof surface

questions.explanation: Attic inspection allows visual confirmation of rafter locations, size, spacing, and condition. Measurements from a reference point (vent pipe, roof edge) transfer to the roof surface. Stud finders often fail through multiple roof layers.

questions.question: If a lag bolt misses the rafter, what should be done?

options.text: Leave it and add another nearby
Fill the hole, seal properly, and install at correct location

questions.explanation: A missed rafter creates a leak point without structural attachment. Remove the lag, fill the hole with appropriate sealant, install flashing if needed, and drill a new hole at the correct rafter location. Don't leave orphan penetrations.

questions.question: Racking rails should be installed with what orientation relative to modules?

options.text: Per manufacturer specifications, typically perpendicular to module long edge

questions.explanation: Most racking systems require rails perpendicular to the module's long edge (portrait orientation) to properly support the frame. Manufacturer specifications define rail spacing based on module dimensions and structural requirements.

questions.question: Rail splices connecting two rail sections should be:

options.text: At or near an attachment point for structural support
At the end of the array

questions.explanation: Rail splices should be located at or near roof attachment points to ensure the splice is structurally supported. Unsupported splices can flex under load, potentially causing equipment damage or array failure.

questions.question: End clamps are used to secure:

options.text: Modules at the outside edges of the array
Modules in the middle of the array

questions.explanation: End clamps secure modules at the perimeter of the array where only one module frame is present. They grip the outer edge of the module frame and fasten to the rail. Mid clamps secure adjacent module frames together.

questions.question: Mid clamps are used to secure:
questions.explanation: Mid clamps secure two adjacent module frames at their junction point with a single fastener. They grip both frames and mount to the rail. Using mid clamps between modules reduces hardware and installation time.

questions.question: Clamps must be positioned within the module manufacturer's specified:
questions.explanation: Module manufacturers specify clamping zones—typically 100-300mm from corners—where the frame is reinforced for mounting loads. Clamping outside this zone can void warranty and risk frame damage under wind/snow loads.

questions.question: Why is proper torque important for PV mounting hardware?

options.text: Under-torque risks loosening; over-torque can damage components

questions.explanation: Proper torque ensures secure connections without damage. Under-torqued fasteners can loosen from vibration and thermal cycling. Over-torqued fasteners can strip threads, crack components, or damage module frames.

questions.question: A torque wrench should be used for:

options.text: All fasteners with specified torque values

questions.explanation: Torque wrenches ensure consistent, correct tightening per manufacturer specifications. This includes lag bolts, module clamps, rail splices, grounding lugs, and electrical connections. Document torque verification for quality assurance.

questions.question: Module frame grounding can be accomplished using:

options.text: Listed grounding washers, lugs, or WEEB clips

questions.explanation: Listed grounding devices (WEEB, lay-in lugs, grounding washers) pierce anodized aluminum to create reliable electrical contact between module frames, racking, and the equipment grounding conductor. Self-tapping screws alone don't ensure proper grounding.

questions.question: When using grounding washers between module frame and clamp, the washer teeth must:

options.text: Penetrate anodizing on both the frame and clamp

questions.explanation: Star washers or grounding washers have teeth that pierce the anodized coating on aluminum to create metal-to-metal contact. Both the module frame and the grounding clamp/rail must be penetrated for proper bonding continuity.

questions.question: PV module cables (home runs) should be:

options.text: Secured to racking, protected from damage, with drip loops
Run through the attic without support

questions.explanation: Cables must be secured to prevent wind damage, abrasion, and wildlife access. Use listed cable clips or ties. Create drip loops at junction boxes so water runs off rather than into connections. Maintain proper bend radius.

questions.question: The minimum bend radius for PV cables is typically:
questions.explanation: Excessive bending damages conductor insulation and can create weak points. Most cable specifications require minimum bend radius of 4-6 times the outer cable diameter. Use gradual curves, not sharp bends, at all routing transitions.

questions.question: MC4-style PV connectors should be installed using:
questions.explanation: MC4 connectors require specific crimping tools to achieve proper compression on the conductor. Assembly tools insert the crimped contact into the housing. Improper assembly causes high resistance, overheating, and potential arc faults.

questions.question: Mixing different brands of PV connectors (e.g., MC4-compatible) is:

options.text: Not recommended—can cause poor connections and void warranties

questions.explanation: While connectors may appear compatible, slight dimensional differences between brands can cause poor contact, water ingress, and premature failure. Use matched connectors from the same manufacturer. Mismatched connectors may void equipment warranties.

questions.question: PV connectors should be mated by:

options.text: Pushing firmly until the locking mechanism engages with an audible click

questions.explanation: Properly mated MC4 connectors produce an audible/tactile click when the internal locking mechanism engages. A firm push (not excessive force) is required. Pull back gently to verify the connection is locked.

questions.question: To disconnect MC4 connectors safely:

options.text: Use the disconnect tool to release the locking mechanism
Use a screwdriver to pry apart

questions.explanation: MC4 connectors have internal locking tabs that require a specific disconnect tool to release. Pulling on cables damages the crimps and can cause future failures. The disconnect tool compresses the locking tabs allowing separation.

questions.question: The typical dead load of a flush-mounted residential PV system is:
questions.explanation: Flush-mounted crystalline silicon systems typically add 2-4 pounds per square foot (psf) dead load including modules, racking, and hardware. Most code-compliant residential roofs can support this additional load without structural modifications.

questions.question: When is a structural engineering analysis typically required for PV installation?

options.text: When dead load exceeds prescriptive limits or roof is non-standard

questions.explanation: Structural analysis is required when loads exceed prescriptive limits, for unusual roof framing, older buildings, ground-mounted systems, carports, or as required by AHJ. Many jurisdictions accept prescriptive compliance letters for standard residential roofs.

questions.question: Wind loads on PV arrays are highest at:

options.text: Corners and edges of the array and roof

questions.explanation: Wind creates highest uplift and turbulence at roof edges, corners, and ridges (Zone 3 per ASCE 7). Arrays in these zones require additional attachments or setbacks. Interior zones (Zone 1) have lowest wind loads.

questions.question: Ballasted mounting systems use weight instead of penetrations and are typically used on:
questions.explanation: Ballasted systems use concrete blocks or integrated weight to hold panels against wind uplift without roof penetrations. Common on flat commercial membrane roofs (TPO, EPDM) where penetrations risk leaks. Roof must support the additional weight.

questions.question: Ballasted systems require additional weight in roof zones with:
questions.explanation: Wind maps show corners and edges experience higher uplift. Ballast layout calculations add more weight blocks in edge and corner zones, with less in interior zones. Software tools optimize ballast distribution while minimizing total weight.

questions.question: Common foundation types for ground-mounted PV include:

options.text: Driven piles, ground screws, concrete ballast, or poured footings

questions.explanation: Ground mount foundations vary by soil conditions and design. Driven steel piles work in most soils, ground screws provide easy installation, concrete ballast blocks work on hard surfaces, and poured footings provide maximum strength in challenging soils.

questions.question: Before installing ground mount foundations, what should be verified?

options.text: Underground utilities (call 811), soil conditions, and setbacks

questions.explanation: Call 811 before digging to locate underground utilities (gas, electric, water, telecom). Verify soil type for foundation design, confirm property setbacks, and check for easements or restricted areas. Hitting utilities is dangerous and costly.

questions.question: Row spacing in ground-mount arrays is determined primarily by:

options.text: Preventing inter-row shading during critical sun hours

questions.explanation: Row spacing prevents shading from one row onto the next during critical production hours (typically 9 AM - 3 PM) at winter solstice when sun is lowest. Spacing depends on latitude, tilt angle, and table height. Tighter spacing sacrifices some winter production.

questions.question: String inverters should be mounted in locations that:

options.text: Receive direct sunlight for best operation
Are shaded, ventilated, and protected from weather

questions.explanation: Inverters generate heat and derate at high temperatures. Mount in shaded, well-ventilated locations—north walls, under eaves, or indoors. Protect from direct rain and maintain manufacturer clearances for airflow. Avoid enclosed unventilated spaces.

questions.question: Inverter mounting height should allow:

options.text: Display visibility and access for maintenance

questions.explanation: Mount inverters at accessible height for monitoring, maintenance, and disconnect operation. Display screens should be visible. Maintain working space per NEC 110.26. Consider future maintenance needs when selecting location.

questions.question: Manufacturer-specified clearances around inverters are important for:
questions.explanation: Inverters require airspace for heat dissipation—blocking vents causes overheating and derating. Service access requires space for DC/AC disconnects, display viewing, and potential replacement. Follow manufacturer specifications exactly.

questions.question: Microinverters are typically mounted:

options.text: Directly behind each PV module on the racking

questions.explanation: Microinverters mount behind each module, typically on the racking rail. They connect to the module's DC output and output AC to a trunk cable. This distributed approach eliminates DC home runs and simplifies string design.

questions.question: The AC trunk cable in a microinverter system connects:

options.text: Modules in series for higher voltage
All microinverters to a common AC circuit

questions.explanation: The trunk cable is a continuous cable with connectors at intervals matching module spacing. Each microinverter plugs into the trunk, which carries combined AC power to the junction box and then to the electrical panel.

questions.question: DC power optimizers are installed:

options.text: Behind each module, between module and string inverter

questions.explanation: Optimizers mount behind each module on the racking. They connect to the module's DC output and output conditioned DC to the string wiring. The string inverter receives optimized DC from all modules in the string.

questions.question: PV conduit exposed on rooftops should be:
questions.explanation: Rooftop conduit must withstand UV, temperature extremes, and physical exposure. EMT or rigid conduit is common; Schedule 80 PVC (gray) is rated for sunlight. Support conduit per NEC 358.30, 352.30. Consider rooftop temperature adder for conductors.

questions.question: When penetrating a roof for conduit, what is required?

options.text: Just drill through and insert conduit
Proper flashing and weatherproofing around the penetration

questions.explanation: Roof penetrations require proper flashing—roof jacks or pitch pockets—to prevent water intrusion. The flashing integrates with roofing material like any other penetration. Conduit must be properly sealed at the roof jack.

questions.question: When routing conduit inside a building to the electrical panel, it should:

options.text: Take the longest path for safety
Take the shortest practical route in accessible locations

questions.explanation: Efficient conduit routing minimizes material cost, voltage drop, and labor. Keep runs accessible for future maintenance. Avoid inaccessible areas where possible. Plan routes during site assessment to account for obstacles.

questions.question: PV junction boxes on rooftops should be:

options.text: Rated for wet locations (NEMA 3R or better)

questions.explanation: Outdoor junction boxes must be suitable for wet locations to prevent water damage to connections. NEMA 3R or 4X ratings are appropriate. Proper knockouts with liquid-tight fittings maintain weatherproofing. Include drains if specified.

questions.question: When transitioning PV source circuit wiring from exposed (on roof) to inside conduit, what fitting is typically required?

options.text: Weatherproof strain relief or weather head

questions.explanation: Transition points where exposed PV cable enters conduit require weatherproof strain relief connectors or weather heads to prevent water entry and cable damage. The fitting must support the cable type and provide proper sealing.

questions.question: Per NEC, PV system labels must be:
questions.explanation: NEC requires durable, permanent labels that remain legible over the system lifetime. Use UV-resistant materials for outdoor labels. Labels are required at disconnects, combiners, main panel, rapid shutdown controls, and as specified by 690.56.

questions.question: What information is required on the label at a DC combiner box?

options.text: Maximum voltage, operating current, maximum current

questions.explanation: Per NEC 690.53, DC junction/combiner boxes must be marked with: maximum system voltage, operating current, operating voltage, maximum circuit current. This helps maintenance personnel understand system parameters.

questions.question: The label at the main service panel for a building with PV must indicate:

options.text: Location of PV disconnect and presence of multiple power sources

questions.explanation: Per NEC 690.56(C), a permanent plaque at the service indicates the PV system disconnect location. Per 705.10, buildings with multiple power sources require directory showing all sources. This informs emergency responders.

questions.question: Rapid shutdown equipment installation requires:

options.text: Listed equipment and installation per manufacturer instructions

questions.explanation: Rapid shutdown equipment must be listed for the application. Installation follows manufacturer instructions for wiring, control connections, and integration. The system must function correctly when tested—verify by opening disconnect and measuring voltage decay.

questions.question: The rapid shutdown initiation device should be located:

options.text: On the roof near the array
At a readily accessible location outside the building

questions.explanation: Per NEC 690.12(C), rapid shutdown initiators must be readily accessible. Often co-located with service disconnect or PV system disconnect. First responders must be able to quickly locate and operate rapid shutdown without special access.

questions.question: Per IFC and typical AHJ requirements, pathways for firefighter access on residential roofs must be at least:
questions.explanation: IFC 605.11 and most AHJs require 36-inch minimum pathways along roof ridges and from eave to ridge for firefighter access. Pathways allow roof ventilation during fire operations. Requirements vary—verify with local AHJ.

questions.question: Fire setbacks from roof edges are typically required at:
questions.explanation: Fire codes typically require 18-36 inch setbacks from edges (eaves), 18-36 inches from ridges, and clear pathways at hips and valleys. These allow firefighter movement and ventilation access. Specific requirements vary by jurisdiction.

questions.question: Per NEC 705.12(B)(2), where should the backfed PV breaker be positioned in the panelboard?

options.text: At the opposite end from the main breaker

questions.explanation: Per NEC 705.12(B)(2)(3)(b), the backfed breaker must be at the opposite (load) end of the busbar from the main breaker. This ensures power flows across the entire busbar, preventing localized overheating.

questions.question: When the 120% rule cannot be satisfied, what alternative exists?

options.text: Reduce main breaker size or use supply-side connection

questions.explanation: If PV breaker + main exceeds 120% of busbar, options include: reducing main breaker size (e.g., 175A main allows 65A PV on 200A bus), or using supply-side connection per NEC 705.12(A) which bypasses the busbar limitation.

questions.question: A supply-side connection taps:

options.text: Between the meter and main service disconnect

questions.explanation: Supply-side connections per NEC 705.12(A) tap between meter and main disconnect, on the line side of service protection. This bypasses busbar limitations but requires service-entrance rated equipment and coordination with utility.

questions.question: Plug-in backfed breakers require what additional hardware?

options.text: A retaining clip or listed fastener

questions.explanation: Per NEC 705.12(B)(7), plug-in type backfed breakers must be secured with an additional fastener to prevent inadvertent removal. Most panel manufacturers provide breaker retaining clips. Bolt-on breakers don't require additional fastening.

questions.question: The AC disconnect for a PV system should be installed:

options.text: Readily accessible, lockable, and grouped with other disconnects

questions.explanation: Per NEC 690.13, the disconnect must be readily accessible (no climbing, removing obstacles) and lockable in the open position. Multiple disconnects should be grouped where practicable. Utility may have additional requirements for location.

questions.question: How many AC disconnects can be grouped as the PV system disconnect per NEC?
questions.explanation: Per NEC 690.13(B), up to 6 switches or circuit breakers can serve as the PV system disconnecting means, similar to service equipment rules. They must be grouped and marked. Most residential systems use a single disconnect for simplicity.

questions.question: Before energizing a new PV system, what tests should be performed?

options.text: Visual inspection, polarity check, Voc, Isc, and insulation resistance

questions.explanation: Per IEC 62446 and industry practice: visual inspection for damage/installation errors, verify polarity and wiring, measure string Voc and compare to expected, measure Isc at known irradiance, test insulation resistance to ground. Document all results.

questions.question: String Voc measurement at commissioning should be within what percentage of calculated value?
questions.explanation: Measured Voc should be within ±5% of calculated Voc (number of modules × module Voc × temperature correction). Significant deviation indicates wiring error (wrong polarity, missing module), bad connection, or defective module.

questions.question: If two strings have Voc values that differ by one module's worth of voltage:

options.text: One string likely has a bypass diode conducting or bad cell

questions.explanation: String Voc difference equal to one module's Voc (typically 40-50V) suggests one module has a conducting bypass diode (heavily shaded cells) or significant cell damage. The affected module needs inspection. Multiple missing 'steps' indicate multiple issues.

questions.question: String Isc measurements at commissioning should compare strings under:
questions.explanation: Compare string Isc values under consistent irradiance conditions. All strings with same orientation should produce similar Isc (within ±5%). Measure sequentially in stable sunlight. Lower Isc indicates shading, soiling, or module issues.

questions.question: Insulation resistance testing at commissioning should show:

options.text: Greater than 1 MΩ between conductors and ground

questions.explanation: Per IEC 62446, insulation resistance should exceed 1 MΩ at 500V or 1000V DC test voltage. Low readings indicate insulation damage, moisture ingress, or wiring faults. Test positive-to-ground and negative-to-ground separately.

questions.question: What documentation should be provided to the system owner at completion?

options.text: As-built drawings, equipment manuals, warranties, and commissioning data

questions.explanation: Complete documentation includes: as-built drawings, equipment datasheets and manuals, warranty documentation, commissioning test results, permit sign-off, utility interconnection approval, monitoring setup, and maintenance recommendations.

questions.question: A pre-installation site visit should verify all EXCEPT:
questions.explanation: Technical site assessment verifies: roof type/condition/dimensions, structural adequacy, shading, azimuth/tilt, electrical panel make/model/ampacity, service size, rafter accessibility, conduit routes, and inverter location. Financial matters are separate.

questions.question: Photo documentation during installation should capture:

options.text: Key stages including roof attachments, wiring, and concealed work

questions.explanation: Document: roof attachment details, flashing installation, rafter connections (before covering), wire routing, combiner wiring, grounding connections, labeling, and final appearance. Photos support warranty claims and quality verification.

questions.question: PV installation should be postponed when:

options.text: Lightning is nearby, winds are high, or rain makes surfaces slippery

questions.explanation: Lightning poses lethal danger on roofs. High winds (typically >25 mph) make module handling dangerous. Wet surfaces are slip hazards. Cold weather is acceptable with proper precautions. Extreme heat requires hydration and rest breaks.

questions.question: In hot weather, installers should:

options.text: Take frequent breaks, hydrate, and watch for heat illness symptoms

questions.explanation: Heat illness prevention per OSHA: hydrate frequently, take breaks in shade, wear appropriate clothing, recognize symptoms (cramps, exhaustion, stroke). Roofs are significantly hotter than ambient temperature. Use a buddy system.

questions.question: When hoisting PV modules to a roof:

options.text: Throw them up one at a time
Use proper lifting equipment and controlled methods

questions.explanation: Use ladders with proper lifting attachments, hoists, or cranes for large installations. Never throw modules. Limit hand-carrying on ladders. Use edge protection and controlled placement. Module weight (50-70 lbs) requires safe handling practices.

questions.question: PV modules should be stored:

options.text: Protected from weather, elevated, and not producing power

questions.explanation: Store modules protected from rain/debris, elevated off ground on pallets, and covered to prevent power generation (shock hazard). Don't stack loose modules—use original packaging. Avoid mechanical stress. Keep connectors capped.

questions.question: Damaged module glass should be handled by:

options.text: Wearing protective gloves and covering the module immediately

questions.explanation: Broken module glass is sharp and the module may still produce voltage. Wear cut-resistant gloves, cover the module with opaque material to reduce voltage, and dispose properly. Document for warranty claim. Don't install damaged modules.

questions.question: When working on energized PV circuits, tools should be:

options.text: Insulated and rated for the voltage present

questions.explanation: Use insulated tools rated for the voltage when working on energized circuits. Even with system 'off,' PV arrays produce voltage in daylight. Insulated screwdrivers, wrenches, and pliers prevent accidental shorts and shock.

questions.question: Power tools used on rooftops should be:

options.text: Battery-powered or connected to GFCI-protected outlets

questions.explanation: Rooftop conditions (moisture, conductive surfaces) increase shock risk. Use battery-powered tools for convenience and safety, or ensure corded tools connect to GFCI-protected circuits. Inspect cords for damage before use.

questions.question: A drill used for lag bolt pilot holes should be:

options.text: Professional-grade with clutch and appropriate power

questions.explanation: Use professional-grade drills with adjustable clutch to prevent overdriving and stripping. Pilot holes require consistent depth control. Impact drivers are useful for driving lags but not for pilot holes. Match drill to the work.

questions.question: When installing on a tile roof, tiles that must be removed should be:

options.text: Carefully removed for reinstallation or replacement
Left in place and drilled through

questions.explanation: Remove tiles carefully to avoid breakage. Use tile hooks that replace the tile with a flashed bracket, or cut/grind tiles to fit around brackets. Have replacement tiles available. Maintain waterproof underlayment integrity.

questions.question: Tile hooks for PV mounting work by:

options.text: Attaching to the roof deck and extending up between or in place of tiles

questions.explanation: Tile hooks bolt to roof rafters through the deck. The hook extends up through the tile coursing—either between tiles, in place of a removed tile, or through a cut-out. Proper flashing maintains waterproofing.

questions.question: Flat roof PV systems often use tilted racking to:

options.text: Improve energy production by orienting modules toward the sun

questions.explanation: Flat roofs receive less irradiance than tilted surfaces. Tilt frames angle modules toward the sun (typically 10-30° for optimal annual production vs. land use). Tilt direction affects shading from adjacent rows.

questions.question: Penetrations in flat roof membranes (TPO, EPDM) require:

options.text: Proper flashing, pitch pockets, or membrane-compatible sealant

questions.explanation: Flat roof penetrations require specialized treatment: membrane boots, pitch pockets, or compatible sealants. TPO requires heat-welded boots; EPDM uses compatible adhesives. Roofing contractor involvement ensures warranty compliance.

questions.question: The seal around a roof penetration should be tested by:

options.text: Visual inspection and water test if accessible

questions.explanation: Visually verify proper flashing installation and sealant application. For accessible areas, a water test (controlled water flow from above while observing below) confirms seal integrity. Document for quality assurance.

questions.question: The DC grounding electrode conductor for a PV system should connect to:

options.text: The existing AC grounding electrode system or bonded supplemental electrode

questions.explanation: Per NEC 690.47, the DC grounding electrode must connect to the AC service grounding electrode system, or to a separate electrode that is bonded to the AC electrode. This maintains equipotential bonding and safety grounding.

questions.question: A supplemental ground rod for a PV system, if installed, must be bonded to the AC electrode using:

options.text: Unspliced 6 AWG copper or larger bonding conductor

questions.explanation: Per NEC 690.47(C), if a separate DC grounding electrode is installed, it must be bonded to the AC grounding electrode using a bonding jumper sized per 250.66 (typically 6 AWG copper minimum). No splices are permitted.

questions.question: If a roof faces east and west only, the installer should:

options.text: Install on both slopes with proper string design and expect ~85% of south-facing production

questions.explanation: East-west installations produce 10-20% less annually than south-facing but provide morning and afternoon peaks. Use separate MPPT inputs for each orientation. This split may better match consumption patterns than south-only arrays.

questions.question: A small vent pipe casts a shadow on one module for 2 hours daily. The impact is:

options.text: Reduces affected string output during shaded period, consider MLPE

questions.explanation: Partial shading on one module reduces the entire series string output. Impact depends on shading severity and duration. Module-level power electronics (optimizers, microinverters) minimize shade impact by allowing each module to operate independently.

questions.question: When possible, shading objects should be placed:

options.text: On the north side of the array
On the south side for aesthetics
As far from modules as possible, or modules relocated to avoid shadow

questions.explanation: Minimize shading by locating conduit, combiner boxes, and other equipment to avoid casting shadows on modules. Relocate small obstructions if possible. Design array layout to avoid existing shade sources like vents, chimneys, and trees.

questions.question: When connecting modules in series, verify:

options.text: All cables are the same color
Positive of one module connects to negative of the next

questions.explanation: Series connections add voltage: positive output of one module to negative input of the next. The string has one positive and one negative end. Incorrect polarity can damage equipment. Verify with voltage measurement before connecting to inverter.

questions.question: When connecting strings in parallel at a combiner, verify:
questions.explanation: Parallel strings must have matching polarity (positive to positive bus, negative to negative bus) and similar voltage (same module count). Verify string Voc is within expected range before combining. Mismatched polarities create dangerous short circuits.

questions.question: Modules should never be carried by:

options.text: The frame edges with two people

questions.explanation: Carrying by cables strains connections and can damage the junction box. Carry modules by the frame—at the short edges for two-person carry, or use proper carriers/straps for one-person handling. Keep modules face-up when possible.

questions.question: Stepping or placing weight on PV modules:

options.text: Can cause micro-cracks that reduce performance and void warranty

questions.explanation: Stepping on modules causes invisible micro-cracks in cells that degrade performance over time. Never place weight on the glass surface. Use proper racking as stepping surfaces. Module manufacturers explicitly prohibit walking on modules.

questions.question: Before installing a module, inspect for:

options.text: Cracked glass, frame damage, junction box damage, cable damage

questions.explanation: Inspect every module for shipping damage: cracked glass, bent frames, damaged junction boxes, cut cables, and delamination. Document damage for warranty claims. Don't install damaged modules—they may fail or underperform.

questions.question: In snowy climates, ground clearance for ground-mount arrays should account for:

options.text: Expected snow accumulation to prevent snow bridging to modules

questions.explanation: Ground clearance must exceed expected snow accumulation to prevent snow from bridging to modules and causing shading, ice damage, or structural stress. Typical clearances range from 2-4 feet depending on snowfall.

questions.question: Snow guards near PV arrays may be installed to:

options.text: Prevent sliding snow from damaging equipment below the array

questions.explanation: Snow guards below arrays prevent snow avalanches from damaging equipment, people, or property. PV modules with frames and glass are slippery—snow sheds quickly and can damage inverters, condensers, or landscaping below.

questions.question: In high-wind zones (hurricane/coastal areas), PV installations require:

options.text: Enhanced attachments, engineering review, and wind-rated equipment

questions.explanation: High-wind zones require racking engineered for local design wind speeds (often 150+ mph), additional roof attachments, specific edge zone treatment, and compliance with enhanced building codes (Florida Building Code, ASCE 7 requirements).

questions.question: Critter guards around PV arrays are installed to:

options.text: Prevent birds, squirrels, and pests from nesting under modules

questions.explanation: Wire mesh or clips around the array perimeter prevent animals from nesting under modules. Nesting materials are fire hazards and can damage wiring. Critter guards are especially important in areas with active wildlife.

questions.question: Sealants used in PV installations should be:

options.text: UV-stable, temperature-rated, and compatible with materials

questions.explanation: Exterior sealants must withstand UV exposure, temperature cycling, and be compatible with roofing materials and flashings. Use manufacturer-recommended products. Polyurethane and appropriate silicones are common. Avoid incompatible sealant combinations.

questions.question: When pulling conductors through conduit, use:

options.text: Wire lubricant and controlled pulling to avoid insulation damage

questions.explanation: Use listed cable lubricant for long or complex pulls to reduce friction and pulling tension. Excessive force damages insulation. Calculate pulling tension limits. Fish tape or pulling rope facilitates long runs. Keep conductors organized.

questions.question: When terminating conductors at breakers and terminals, ensure:

options.text: Proper strip length, torque to specification, and correct conductor type

questions.explanation: Strip conductors to manufacturer-specified length (not too long or short). Torque to specifications using calibrated torque tool. Verify conductor is rated for the terminal (copper-only vs Cu/Al). Poor terminations cause overheating.

questions.question: The maximum temperature rating on a terminal connection point determines:

options.text: Which column of the ampacity table to use for the connected conductor

questions.explanation: Per NEC 110.14(C), conductor ampacity at terminals is limited by the terminal temperature rating (typically 60°C or 75°C). Even if the conductor is rated 90°C, ampacity must be based on the lower terminal rating unless terminals are rated higher.

questions.question: Stainless steel hardware is preferred for PV installations because:

options.text: It resists corrosion from weather exposure

questions.explanation: Stainless steel resists corrosion from rain, humidity, salt air, and chemical exposure. Most quality racking uses stainless steel fasteners. Coastal installations especially require stainless to prevent premature failure from salt corrosion.

questions.question: Galvanic corrosion between aluminum racking and steel bolts can be prevented by:

options.text: Using stainless steel or proper isolation between dissimilar metals

questions.explanation: Dissimilar metals in contact with electrolyte (moisture) cause galvanic corrosion. Stainless steel is compatible with aluminum. If using other metals, isolate with compatible washers or coatings. Racking manufacturers specify compatible hardware.

questions.question: When installing lithium battery storage systems, follow:

options.text: Manufacturer instructions, NEC 706, and local fire codes

questions.explanation: Battery installations require compliance with NEC Article 706, manufacturer requirements, and local fire codes. This includes proper ventilation, spacing, fire separation, disconnect requirements, and overcurrent protection. Location restrictions may apply.

questions.question: Battery system disconnects must be:

options.text: Readily accessible, lockable, and properly rated

questions.explanation: Per NEC 706.15, ESS disconnects must be lockable in open position and readily accessible. They must simultaneously disconnect all ungrounded conductors and be rated for maximum ESS current and voltage. Location per manufacturer and code.

questions.question: Production monitoring system installation typically requires:

options.text: Internet connection, CT sensors, and proper configuration

questions.explanation: Monitoring requires internet connectivity (WiFi or Ethernet), current transformers (CTs) to measure production/consumption, and configuration through manufacturer app or portal. Verify communication before leaving site. Train customer on monitoring access.

questions.question: Before calling for final electrical inspection, verify:

options.text: All labels installed, disconnects operational, grounding complete, documentation ready

questions.explanation: Pre-inspection checklist: all required labels in place, disconnects operational and accessible, grounding complete and tight, conductor terminations torqued, rapid shutdown functional, documentation available. System need not be energized for inspection.

questions.question: Customer orientation at project completion should cover:

options.text: System operation, monitoring access, maintenance, warranties, and safety

questions.explanation: Walk customers through: disconnect locations and operation, monitoring system access, expected production, maintenance requirements (cleaning, inspections), warranty contacts, safety precautions, and what to do if issues occur. Provide written documentation.

questions.question: Before energizing a new PV system, what utility coordination is typically required?

options.text: Interconnection agreement approval and possible meter change

questions.explanation: Utility requires signed interconnection agreement before operation. Net metering requires bi-directional meter (utility installs or replaces). Some utilities require inspection. Never energize before utility approval—may void agreement.

questions.question: If an inspector cites a code violation, the installer should:
questions.explanation: Correct cited violations per inspector requirements, document the correction, and schedule re-inspection. Discuss unclear requirements professionally. Appeal through proper channels if you believe the citation is incorrect. Don't energize until approved.

questions.question: Underground conduit for PV wiring must be installed at minimum depth per:

options.text: NEC Table 300.5 based on conduit type and location

questions.explanation: NEC Table 300.5 specifies minimum burial depths: rigid metal conduit (6"), intermediate metal conduit (6"), rigid PVC (18"), and direct burial cables (24" typically). Depths vary by location (under driveways, etc.).

questions.question: Before excavating for underground PV conduit:
questions.explanation: Always call 811 before digging. Utilities will mark gas, electric, water, sewer, and telecom lines. Hitting a utility line can cause injury, death, service disruption, and significant liability. Wait for all utilities to respond before excavating.

questions.question: Warning tape above underground electrical conduit should be installed:

options.text: At the bottom of the trench

questions.explanation: Detectable warning tape should be buried 12 inches above underground cables/conduit to warn future excavators before they reach the energized circuits. The tape should be detectable by metal detectors and brightly colored (typically red for electrical).

questions.question: Pull boxes in long conduit runs serve to:

options.text: Facilitate wire pulling and provide access for future maintenance

questions.explanation: Pull boxes break long runs into manageable sections, provide splice points if needed, and allow access for future maintenance or modifications. They're required when conduit runs exceed pulling limits or have too many bends.

questions.question: When designing string layout, modules in the same string should:

options.text: Have the same orientation, tilt, and shading conditions

questions.explanation: Series-connected modules in a string should have matched conditions (orientation, tilt, shading) to operate at similar current. Mixing conditions reduces string output to the lowest-performing module. Use separate strings or MLPE for different orientations.

questions.question: Recording module serial numbers and locations during installation is important for:

options.text: Warranty claims, troubleshooting, and monitoring system setup

questions.explanation: Module mapping (serial numbers, positions) enables warranty claims for specific modules, troubleshooting of underperformers identified by monitoring, and accurate as-built documentation. Many monitoring systems require serial number entry during configuration.

questions.question: Solar carport and shade structure installations require additional consideration for:

options.text: Structural engineering, vehicle clearance, and drainage

questions.explanation: Carports require structural engineering for self-supporting design, adequate vehicle clearance (typically 9-14 feet), proper drainage (gutters/scuppers), wind load analysis for open structures, and foundation design for the specific soil conditions.

questions.question: The final step before leaving a completed PV installation is typically:

options.text: Verify system is producing power correctly and document
Take a photo for social media

questions.explanation: After utility approval, verify system is operational: check inverter display for normal production, verify monitoring communication, compare actual output to expected, confirm no error codes, and document commissioning readings. Clean up the site completely.
